fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of an unknown man, formerly said to be John Thurloe, watercolour on vellum, English school, ca.1645-1655.

fields.name: Historical Collection of Miniatures formed by Mr J Lumsden Propert

fields.physical_description:
Portrait of a man, head and shoulders, turned slightly to left, looking to front and wearing a white collar.  Features in very broad rapid strokes of brown, sanguine, blue and grey, with touches of white, laid directly beside one another, some dragged and interrupted, and completely unblended into the pale carnation ground; hair in very dark brown wash, the lights in pale grey and pale brown gouache; collar in pale grey wash, modelled in thick white; robe in dark grey wash with the lights in pale grey; background a sky in blue, grey, red and yellow gouache washes; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. 

<u>Frame:</u>  A turned oval of ebonised fruitwood.
fields.title: Unknown Man, formerly said to be John Thurloe
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.exhibition_history:
Historical Collection of Miniatures formed by Mr J Lumsden Propert (Fine Art Society 01/01/1897-31/12/1897)
Exhibition of Portrait Miniatures (Burlington Fine Arts Club 1889-1889)
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.184, pp. 310-311. Full citation: “Unknown Man, formerly said to be John Thurloe (b. 1616 d. 1668) c.1645-55 P111-1910 Oval 75 x 60 mm Features in very broad rapid strokes of brown, sanguine, blue and grey, with touches of white, laid directly beside one another, some dragged and interrupted, and completely unblended into the pale carnation ground; hair in very dark brown wash, the lights in pale grey and pale brown gouache; collar in pale grey wash, modelled in thick white; robe in dark grey wash with the lights in pale grey; background a sky in blue, grey, red and yellow gouache washes; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Some slight condensation spots, as on the sitter's left cheek; otherwise good. Signed: Not signed. Frame: A turned oval of ebonised fruitwood. Provenance: By 1887, J L Propert; purchased with others from the Propert Collection by George Salting, (1) and by him bequeathed to the Museum, 1910. Exhibited: BFAC 1889, p. 98, case XXXIV, no. 6, pl. XI (as Thurloe by Cooper); FAS 1897, no. 49. Literature: Propert 1887, repro. facing p. 78; Williamson 1904, vol. I, p. 74, pl. XXXVII, no. 2 (as Thurloe by Cooper, owner unknown); Foster 1911 (‘The other Coopers comprise ... the heavy lymphatic face of Secretary Thurloe’): Foster 1914-16, vol. II, p. 71, nos 461-2 (both entries are for this miniature); Long 1930, p. 13 (as ascribed to Cooper and 'on bone'); Colding 1953, p. 124; Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 9 (as said to be Thurloe and formerly ascribed to Cooper). The miniature seems to derive from images which were, in the eighteenth century, accepted as being of Thurloe, Secretary of State in charge of Foreign Affairs under the Commonwealth. Several prints, including especially the engraving by T Chambers published in Smollett's History of England (1757), and deriving variously from Houbraken in 1738, were stated in the publication line to come ultimately from Cooper. Significantly, the prints are in the opposite sense from the miniature, which would have reinforced the belief that the present miniature was the original of this portrait type. Since Piper 1963, however, the accepted images of Thurloe have been those of the type represented in the NPG and propagated in the eighteenth century through Vertue's engraving of 1741. In addition, a miniature in the Buccleuch Collection (2) 'agrees well enough in features’ (3) and is tentatively included in Davies's listing. (4) The Cooper/Houbraken type, on the other hand, 'probably does not represent' Thurloe, according to Piper, a judgement accepted by Davies. As to the artist, the attribution to Cooper has long since been abandoned. Reynolds, influenced by the eighteenth-century acceptance of this image of Thurloe, noted in the departmental copy of Long 1930 'an eighteenth-century fake'. Long's judgement had been more tolerant: in his usage the phrase 'ascribed to' implied a higher degree of credence than it does now. He would have been influenced by the quality of the draughtsmanship in the face-painting, which is fast and accurate and, although not by a recognisable hand, is well within the range of normal mid-seventeenth-century technical practice. The slightly mechanical way of modelling the features in long strokes of the brush laid beside one another suggests an influence from the craft of engraving. This could be because the artist was in this instance copying a particular print (as Reynolds might argue), or because he was himself an engraver, (5) or because he had learnt to draw partly from engravings in teaching books (as Snelling may have done). Jim Murrell's comment, preserved in a note in the conservation record on this miniature, was 'features in coarse washy strokes (vide Snelling)'. The miniature does not to my eye actually look like a Snelling, though perhaps if he had been copying a Cooper, the result might have been something like this. Earlier, the miniature had been a victim of the myth that Cooper sometimes painted on bone. (6) Long spent some time worrying about this, rather than working on the iconography or thinking seriously about the authorship. He noted: ' I took out the backboard on 30.1.11, but the miniature, which appeared to be on bone (!) & was goldbeatered on to the glass, would not easily come out, so I left it.' Later (8.9.13), still without stripping the gold-beater's skin, he commented: 'Judging from the back of the min. it is on bone. The surface does not look quite like the usual "prepared" card.’ (7) Long's reluctance to dismantle objects was admirable, even when as here the fixings were the work of a recent restorer or framer. When the miniature was eventually released from attachment to the glass, it was obvious that the secondary support was the normal table-book leaf. 1 Salting Collection, no. 4626. 2 Kennedy 1917. p. 36. as in the style of or after Samuel Cooper. 3 Piper 1963, p. 344. 4 Davies 1979, vol.Lp. 136.p. 136. 5 Faithorne was said by de Piles to have painted in miniature, though no works are known to have survived. 6 See Williamson 1904, vol. I. p. 77; Williamson cites a miniature in his own collection as an example of the practice, but confuses it with the present miniature in his reference to the illustrations of both on pl. XXXVII. See also Cat. No.199 [607-1882]. 7 Departmental files."
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> By 1887, J L Propert; purchased with others from the Propert Collection by George Salting, and by him bequeathed to the Museum, 1910.
